headline.main: Wishes and Qualms Of Centrists on Health Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama held a prime-time news conference in the White House’s East Room to discuss his plan to overhaul the nation’s health care system.
docs.snippet: President Obama held a prime-time news conference in the White House’s East Room to discuss his plan to overhaul the nation’s health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Measuring the Appeal | 9:14 p.m. From Adam Nagourney: Mr. Obama's audience tonight was not Republicans or Democrats who have resisted his health care plan, but rather the general public. For nearly an hour, often speaking in a monotone, Mr. Obama sought to make the case to the public that his health care plan was essential for the long-term economic health of the country.
docs.abstract: Stay with us for updates throughout the president's news conference.
docs.snippet: Stay with us for updates throughout the president's news conference.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER, HELENE COOPER and ADAM NAGOURNEY

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House has released excerpts of the remarks President Obama will make before he begins taking questions at tonight's news conference. It begins at 8 p.m. and will be broadcast live from the White House on most networks and cable stations. We'll be back live blogging just as it begins.
docs.abstract: The president talks a lot about health care in his prepared statements for tonight.
docs.snippet: The president talks a lot about health care in his prepared statements for tonight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thank you for responding and submitting questions you would want to ask President Obama before the news conference at 8 p.m. Many of you chose to address health care, which is expected to be one of the president's major topics tonight as Congress is buckling down on varying drafts of legislation to overhaul the system. Other questions posed concerned the economy, the future of space travel and immigration.

headline.main: Caucus Readers' Questions for the President

docs.abstract: Health care dominates what's on people's minds.
docs.snippet: Health care dominates what's on people's minds.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday we noted that young people, who are more likely to support a major health care overhaul, are also (not coincidentally) less likely to have health insurance.
docs.abstract: Hispanics, those making under $36,000 and those under 30 are the groups most likely to lack coverage, a Gallup survey shows.
docs.snippet: Hispanics, those making under $36,000 and those under 30 are the groups most likely to lack coverage, a Gallup survey shows.

docs.lead_paragraph: Generally overlooked in the debate over health care reform, and of particular interest to New Old Age readers, is the C.L.A.S.S. Act, a bill introduced by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that would establish a national long-term care insurance program. The idea has circulated for years, but now advocates think there's a real possibility such a plan will be incorporated into whatever health care bill emerges from Congress.
docs.abstract: Legislators are quietly considering creation of a public insurance program for long-term care.
docs.snippet: Legislators are quietly considering creation of a public insurance program for long-term care.
